Award.AwardTitle: RET in Engineering and Computer Science Site for Sustainable Polymer Engineering Research

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for a three year standard award to support a Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) in Engineering and Computer Science Site program at the University of Southern Mississippi (USM) entitled, "RET in Engineering and Computer Science Site for Sustainable Polymer Engineering Research", under the direction of Dr. Sarah E. Morgan.

The University of Southern Mississippi proposes to host ten local community college instructors and high school teachers per year for three year for a six-week summer research experience with polymer science and engineering faculty members to perform research in the area of sustainable sustainable materials. Teachers will work in pairs with faculty and student researchers in efforts focused on addressing 21st century grand challenges in engineering. The overall objective of the program is to develop long-term professional relationships between faculty researchers and local teachers by providing meaningful research experiences in relevant polymer engineering research efforts and establishing follow-up activities to extend the impact of the program throughout the school year. Professional development and training in fundamentals of polymer engineering, high performance teams, and scientific communication will be provided.

The proposed sustainable materials engineering research platform provides the framework to build long-term relationships between engineering faculty and teachers while providing cutting-edge research experiences that are readily incorporated into high school and community college science curricula. The increasing demand for energy and use of hydrocarbons create a wide range of issues, such as the Deepwater Horizon BP Oil Spill of 2010 off the Mississippi Gulf Coast, as well as opportunities, such as production of agriculturally based polymers and alternative energy development, which have high impact on Mississippi teachers and students. The proposed RET will immerse high school teachers and community college faculty in sustainable polymer engineering research in three areas: (1) improved efficiency polymer solar cells, (2) high performance polymers and composites from renewable feedstocks, and (3) environmental impact of synthetic materials in sea water. The proposed effort is a transformative platform for engaging the public in sustainable materials engineering research through relevant research experiences that will resonate with teachers, students and parents. Faculty and graduate student mentors will participate in classroom activities during the school year to ensure the impact of the RET program through the school year.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The RET Site for Sustainable Polymer Engineering Research (RET) at The University of Southern Mississippi School of Polymer Science and Engineering hosted nineteen different high school and community college science faculty from eleven institutions with high levels of minority and economically disadvantaged student populations for a six-week summer research experience.  The sustainable materials engineering research platform of the RET site provided a framework to build long-term relationships between engineering faculty and teachers through cutting-edge research experiences that are readily incorporated into high school and community college science curricula.  Teachers participated in sustainable polymer engineering research in areas including polymer-based solar cells; high performance polymers and composites from renewable feedstocks; and environmental impact of synthetic materials in the ocean. Teachers prepared research-based curriculum modules for implementation in the classroom.  Graduate students and faculty mentors visited teacher classrooms to assist in laboratory activities and delivery of research-based modules. Teachers presented 12 workshops at the Mississippi Science Teachers Association annual meeting over the three years of the program to make research activities available for MS teachers.  RET participants presented a workshop at the 2017 national American Chemical Society (ACS) spring meeting and distributed 100 kits of polymer science classroom activities to participating teachers.  Eleven additional presentations were made at ACS national meetings in the Division of Chemical Education and Division of Polymer Chemistry by RET participants and six curriculum modules were accepted for publication in Teach Engineering.  Research activities are available on the RET website https://www.usm.edu/polymer/teacher-outreach.  Sustained activities through the school year include field trips by RET classes to the Polymer Science Research Center for hands-on activities, tours and lectures (600 students per year), science fair mentorship by graduate students, and after-school shadowing and laboratory experiences.  The program has served to raise awareness of polymer science and engineering careers and applications in high schools across the state and has encouraged students to pursue studies in STEM fields. Two teacher participants in the RET (Rebecca Hooper and James Brownlow) were selected as winners of the 2018 William Dahlgren Teacher of Excellence Award through the Society for the Advancement of Material and Process Engineering (SAMPE).
